Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Investigation of Attosecond and Femtosecond Dynamics in Atoms and Molecules using XUV+IR Spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will allow for the establishment of a strong research and educational development program in the field of ultrafast atomic, molecular, and optical sciences in the Department of Physics at the University of Arizona. The program will study atomic and molecular response to strong transient electric fields with simultaneous use of IR and XUV pulses in attosecond precision experiments. This will involve measurement and control of electronic and nuclear dynamics in highly-excited molecules using attosecond/femtosecond resolved pump-probe experiments. Ultrashort XUV excitation provides direct access to an interesting and challenging regime, where atoms and molecules are energetically far from their ground-state configuration. Using attosecond time-resolved XUV+IR experiments, we can measure the effect of strong electric fields on excited bound-state wavepackets in atomic systems. These measurements will offer new opportunities for the control of electron dynamics on attosecond time-scales. In molecules, the XUV excitation is associated with fast inner-valence electron phenomenon, correlated two-electron processes, and strongly interdependent electronic and nuclear dynamics. The understanding of time-resolved dynamics in this regime has been very limited due to the spectroscopic difficulties in probing inherently low cross-section photo-fragmentation channels; the complexity of the potential energy surface manifold in highly-excited systems; and the paucity of efficient, tunable, femtosecond/attosecond XUV photon sources. This project aims at investigating this regime by utilizing cutting-edge research tools, such as, tailored XUV pulses, and efficient photo-fragment imaging schemes.

The broader aspects include the CAREER educational objectives that will increase the representation of Hispanic students in physics research; directly involve undergraduate students in ultrafast science research; and lead to the development and web-based dissemination of interactive learning programs. This training and outreach, along with the forefront research will help make our nation more competitive in the field of attosecond and femtosecond science. The educational plan targets students from an under-represented group. In collaboration with a primarily Hispanic institution (UTEP), Hispanic students will obtain hands-on experience and vital exposure in a cutting edge field of research. With the involvement of graduate and undergraduate students, the educational program leads to the development of interactive learning programs in optics/AMO, along with a method for web-based publication and dissemination, in a manner that will be useful to wider community. The research spin-offs of this program will be in the form of new insights and discoveries, which will impact other related fields such as quantum optics, theoretical atomic and molecular physics, coherent control, atmospheric chemistry, chemical imaging and radiation chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Contemporary science is largely driven by the desire to understand and control phenomena occurring far beyond the spatial and temporal confines of our senses. Our research embodies this through the study of fundamental atomic and molecular processes that take place on extremely short timescales approaching a billionth of a billionth of a second, or an attosecond. We employed the newly developed attosecond spectroscopy tools to understand, characterize and control electron dynamics in systems such as helium, oxygen and carbon dioxide. Extreme ultraviolet (XUV) attosecond pulse trains were utilized in conjunction with strong laser fields to excite and probe electronic and nuclear wave packets, whose evolution is the essence of many physical and chemical phenomena.

Atomic and molecular structure is highly dynamic in the presence of an intense laser pulse. Using attosecond resolved experiments, we monitored the ionization in the presence of a strong field and obtained precision measurements of quantum interferences between photo-excitation paths. The knowledge of quantum phases of excitation channels opens the doors for photo absorption control schemes, to tailor the temporal and spectral properties of XUV light passing through laser-dressed atoms. We also developed a new technique to measure absolute timing of attosecond XUV bursts produced in high-harmonic generation process.

We investigated oxygen molecules that exist in neutral form at energies far above their ionization potential. Such super excited molecules are found as intermediates in reactions initiated by energetic photons (e.g., solar radiation) and play an important role in the chemistry of planetary atmospheres. The super excited molecules quickly relax from their non-equilibrium state through multiple competing decay mechanisms. Using XUV excitation and near-infrared (NIR) laser probing, we quantified the timescales for autoionization and dissociation processes responsible for the relaxation of oxygen molecule.

In a major step forward in the experimental study of complex molecular dynamics, we employed XUV and NIR pulses to monitor the coherent electron hole dynamics near a conical intersection of a polyatomic molecule. The motion of electrons or holes across a molecule is crucial in many biochemical processes. Common examples include damage and repair of DNA, ultrafast charge migration in peptides, light-harvesting in photosynthetic compounds. We not only measured the timescale of the electron hole transfer but also quantified the strength of the electron-nuclear coupling mechanism responsible of charge dynamics in carbon dioxide molecule. 

In contrast to the previous studies conducted in the single atom regime, we investigated attosecond transient absorption lineshapes in dense media. We obtained understanding of the interplay between resonant pulse propagation and laser-induced phase effects, and related that to the observed spectral and temporal properties of the XUV radiation. Our work established a criterion for determining when collective effects cannot be ignored in attosecond transient absorption. 

Under the educational objectives of this program, apart from creating opportunities for the graduate students, we worked to increase the participation of undergraduate students and underrepresented minorities in advanced physics research. This led to the training a next generation of scientists, which along with the expected research output, makes our nation more competitive in the frontier areas scientific research.

The ‘real-time’ measurement of coherent, non-adiabatic electron dynamics in complex systems is the holy grail of ultrafast science. By demonstrating that ultrafast XUV sources can resolve the motion of an electron hole in a polyatomic, we have opened a path towards new studies in molecules and materials. The successful investigations of such dynamics will serve to establish attosecond science as an interdisciplinary technique with a broad applicability in chemistry, biology, and material sciences.
